content: The "Congestion Relief Act of 2005" includes provisions for the Surface Transportation Program, dividing funds between urbanized areas and other areas, and adjusting obligation authority for fiscal years. It also addresses the Congestion Mitigation and Air Quality Improvement Program. The "Congestion Relief Act of 2005" amends Section 149 of title 23, United States Code, regarding the allocation of apportioned funds to metropolitan planning organizations and agencies responsible for air quality conformity determinations in federally designated areas based on population ratios. The "Congestion Relief Act of 2005" amends Section 149 of title 23, United States Code, to allocate funds based on population ratios in nonattainment and maintenance areas. States can reallocate funds to prevent lapses and provide obligation authority to agencies for eligible projects under the surface transportation program. The "Congestion Relief Act of 2005" amends Section 149 of title 23, United States Code, to allocate obligation authority to States for Federal-aid highways and highway safety construction programs based on population ratios in nonattainment and maintenance areas. States can redistribute funds to prevent lapses and provide obligation authority to agencies for eligible projects. The "Congestion Relief Act of 2005" amends Section 149 of title 23, United States Code to allocate obligation authority to States for Federal-aid highways and highway safety construction programs based on population ratios in nonattainment and maintenance areas. Each State, metropolitan planning organization, and the Secretary have joint responsibility to ensure compliance. The "Congestion Relief Act of 2005" amends Section 149 of title 23, United States Code to allocate obligation authority to States for Federal-aid highways and highway safety construction programs based on population ratios in nonattainment and maintenance areas. Each State, metropolitan planning organization, and the Secretary have joint responsibility to ensure compliance. The Act also includes provisions related to the National Highway System. The "Congestion Relief Act of 2005" amends Section 149 of title 23, United States Code to allocate obligation authority to States for Federal-aid highways and highway safety construction programs based on population ratios in nonattainment and maintenance areas. The Act also includes provisions related to the National Highway System. Section 103 of title 23 is further amended to address project selection requirements and allocation of funds to urbanized areas with a population of over 200,000. The "Congestion Relief Act of 2005" amends Section 149 of title 23, United States Code to allocate obligation authority to States for Federal-aid highways and highway safety construction programs based on population ratios in nonattainment and maintenance areas. It also includes provisions related to the National Highway System, specifically allocating funds to urbanized areas based on vehicle miles traveled ratios. The "Congestion Relief Act of 2005" amends Section 105(c)(2) of title 23, United States Code by adjusting the paragraphs referenced. Additionally, it introduces a Metropolitan Congestion Relief Program. The "Congestion Relief Act of 2005" introduces a Metropolitan Congestion Relief Program under Section 165 of title 23, United States Code. Eligible projects must meet requirements of the surface transportation program and planning regulations. The organization must show that the project will improve congestion in its region. Funding will be apportioned to metropolitan planning organizations in urbanized areas with specific criteria. The Secretary determines eligibility and apportions funding based on travel time index and passenger miles traveled in urbanized areas. Appropriations are authorized from the Highway Trust Fund for this purpose. Appropriated $2 billion annually from the Highway Trust Fund for fiscal years 2004-2009. Definitions for travel time index and passenger miles traveled are provided. Conforming amendment made to the analysis for chapter 1 of title 23, United States Code. SEC. 7. Transportation operational improvement program aimed at relieving metropolitan congestion. The operational improvement program aims to provide grants for projects to enhance the operation of roadways, including incident management projects like developing coordinated plans for accidents and purchasing telecommunications equipment for first responders. The operational improvement program provides grants for projects to enhance roadway operation, including purchasing equipment for first responders, deploying intelligent transportation systems technology, and implementing transportation demand management techniques such as commuter benefit and parking management programs. The operational improvement program provides grants for projects to enhance roadway operation, including various initiatives such as carpool projects, ride matching operations, real-time traveler information programs, telework programs, bicycle and pedestrian programs, access to transit investments, commuter-friendly facilities, and transit shuttle planning. $500,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2004 to 2009 from the Highway Trust Fund for these projects. The operational improvement program provides grants for projects to enhance roadway operation, including carpool projects, real-time traveler information programs, and transit shuttle planning. $500,000,000 is authorized annually from 2004 to 2009 from the Highway Trust Fund for these initiatives. All provisions of this chapter applicable to National Highway System funds apply to funds for this program, except for specific limitations. SEC. 8. METROPOLITAN PLANNING FUNDS. Section 104(f)(1) of title 23, United States Code, is amended by increasing the percentage from "1 percent" to "2 percent".
